newsitem.title: ESTONIA: GOVERNMENT SEES 4-5 PCT GDP GROWTH.
newsitem.headline: GOVERNMENT SEES 4-5 PCT GDP GROWTH.

text.p: The Estonian government said on Friday that its new programme calls for four to five percent GDP growth and aims to hold inflation to 10-12 percent in 1997-98.

"A conservative fiscal policy, a liberal foreign trade policy suitable for a small country, enterpreneuship based mostly on private ownership and a tax policy and legislative environment that favours economic development will remain the basis of Estonia's economic policy," the government said.
Estonia's budget and monetary policy will continuously be based on a balanced state budget and currency board, the government said.
The 1998 state budget avoids the rise in tax burden and increases the stake of state investments in state costs.
The government also plans to sign a new memorandum with International Monetary Fund (IMF).
The government will decrease the stake of direct taxes and increase the stake of indirect taxes, such as excise tax, the said.
The government will favour regional investments, and apply corporate income tax exemptions on investments made in poor regions.
To keep a lid on inflation and maintain economic stability, the government will continue a conservative foreign lending policy, it said.
It will also increase tax collection and reduce the size of the shadow economy and push for cooperation between tax, customs and policy authorities.
The government plans to reduce the state's stake in business and complete the privatisation of industrial, trade, transport and service companies and start the sell-off of infrastructure companies.
It also said that it will continue to seek entry into foreign markets through negotiations with the European Union, Russia, Central and Eastern European countries and other states.
Foreign policy goals include joining the World Trade Organisation this year, it said, adding that the law on customs tariffs needs to be passed fist.
EU integration will remain a top priority.
"We will do everything possible to be in the first group of countries joining the European Union," it said.
The cornerstone of security policy is integration into western defence organisations, NATO membership, and strengthening of the country's own defence abilities.
Estonia will actively continue participation in NATO's Partnership for Partnerhip programme and is ready to support other new NATO initiatives.
